page.title: 01The upland NE of Uig, Skye
page.content: The upland is steeply sloping heather and scrub moorland falling to the west. Its eastern border ends in a sheer cliff face of 300ft, a section of the Trottenish Ridge. The area is dissected by several streams which form gorges and water falls. The area is totally uninhabited and use is almost exclusively sheep grazing and marginal cattle grazing. Small pockets of the area are still used for non- commercial peat cutting. The region is the natural habitat to varied bird and wildlife including eagles, otters, buzzards and fox. Numerous species of alpine and native flora exist including wild orchid.
